image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from South Carolina; born in Conway, Horry County, S.C., May 19, 1936; graduated from Loris High School, Loris, S.C., 1954; B.A., Wofford College, Wofford, S.C., 1958; LL.B., University of South Carolina Law School, Columbia, S.C., 1962; admitted to the South Carolina bar, 1962; served as North Myrtle Beach city judge, 1962-1965; city attorney, 1965-1969; member of the South Carolina house of representatives, 1964-1972; unsuccessful candidate for election to the Ninety-third Congress in 1972; delegate, Democratic National Conventions, 1974, 1980; elected as a Democrat to the Ninety-fourth and to the two succeeding Congresses, until his resignation on December 10, 1980, (November 5, 1975-December 10, 1980); president of an advertising and public relations firm in Florence and Myrtle Beach, S.C.; is a resident of North Myrtle Beach, S.C.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Clark, John F. Capitol Steps and Missteps: The Wild, Improbable Ride of Congressman John Jenrette. North Charleston, South Carolina: Self-Published, CreateSpace, 2017.
Jenrette, Rita. My Capitol Secrets. New York: Bantam Books, 1981.

researchRecord.name: In the Joseph L. Rauh papers, ca. 1913-1986, 86.4 linear feet.

researchRecord.name: In the John Light Napier papers, 1979-1982, 6 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Collection includes two audio and one video concerning debates between John Napier and John Jenrette during the 1980 campaign.

researchRecord.name: In the records of AFL-CIO Committee on Political Education (COPE), Area 3, 1947-1979, 1.5 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: Collection includes campaign materials from John Jenrette's 1972 campaign for Congress.

researchRecord.name: In the papers of Joseph L. Rauh, 1913-1994, 115.6 linear feet.
1974, 7 commercials on 1 film reel.
researchRecord.description: The commercials were used during John Jenrette's campaign for the 1974 U.S. congressional election in South Carolina, District 6, Democratic Party.
